plugins.name: Create Red Rectangle Plugin
plugins.description:
Objective: Implement functionality where clicking a button creates a red rectangle on the workspace.


Implementation Plan:


Creating the Interface:


Add a button labeled "Create Rectangle."

Prepare a canvas or container where the rectangle will appear.

Styling Elements:


Define styles for the button (e.g., color, shape).

Set default dimensions and properties for the rectangle (e.g., width, height, background color).

Programming Logic:


Write an event handler for the button: on click, create an element with predefined properties (e.g., width, height, color).

Append this element to the container on the page.

Testing the Functionality:


Ensure the red rectangle appears correctly and only when the button is clicked.

Optionally, add features such as slightly offsetting the position of each new rectangle.
plugins.tagline: Rectangle

plugins.name: JSONify
plugins.description:
Export Text Layers as JSON


JSONify simplifies your workflow by automatically converting selected text layers into structured JSON data.


In JSONify, each Figma layer‚Äôs name becomes a key in the exported JSON, and the text content within the layer becomes its corresponding value.


For example, a layer named "title" containing the text "Hello World!" would generate the following JSON entry:

"title": "Hello World! (classic üòâ)"


This straightforward mapping keeps your exported JSON organized, clean, and easy to integrate - directly reflecting the structure of your design.


How the Plugin Works


  1. Layer names = Object keys: Each layer name becomes a key in the exported JSON object.
  2. Line breaks = Array items: Text containing line breaks (\n) is split into an array of strings.
  3. Groups = Arrays: Grouped text layers are exported as array items under the group's name.
  4. Prefix ‚Äúexclude-‚Äù to skip: Any layer whose name starts with exclude- will be excluded from the export.


üñ§ Open-source & community-driven! Check out the code or contribute: https://github.com/ko-ko-lo/figma-json-export


üí¨ Feedback, ideas, or just want to say hi? Drop a comment - I‚Äôd love to hear from you!

plugins.name: Move Outside
plugins.description:
A plugin designed to move any elements outside of their current frames and place them at the top of the hierarchy while retaining their original position relative to the entire page. The plugin offers two modes:


  1. Default - Moves selected single or multiple elements to the top of the page‚Äôs layer hierarchy.
  2. Locked Target - Moves selected single or multiple elements into another specified layer. The Locked Target mode supports moving into frames, frames with autolayout, and sections. If the Locked Target is an autolayout frame, users can choose whether the moved frames should retain their original page position using absolute positioning or adapt to the autolayout.


This plugin stands out from others with similar functionality by offering a full interface that enables continuous management of complex layer structures.
plugins.tagline: A plugin used to move elements to the top of the layer hierarchy or to other frames/sections.

plugins.name: SVG Exporter
plugins.description:
Este plugin te permite exportar elementos gr√°ficos (assets) en formato SVG desde cualquier Frame que selecciones en Figma. Al ejecutarlo:

1. El plugin detecta autom√°ticamente los vectores, √≠conos y componentes dentro del frame seleccionado.

2. Muestra una lista con vista previa de cada asset, su nombre y tipo (VECTOR, LINE, COMPONENT, etc.).

3. Puedes filtrar por tipo, seleccionar o deseleccionar assets individualmente o todos a la vez.

4. Al hacer clic en ‚ÄúExportar selecci√≥n‚Äù, los archivos se descargan en un ZIP listo para usar.


Uso paso a paso:

‚Ä¢ Selecciona un Frame que contenga los assets que deseas exportar.

‚Ä¢ Ejecuta el plugin.

‚Ä¢ Filtra, selecciona y exporta.


Limitaciones actuales:

‚Ä¢ Solo funciona si seleccionas un Frame (no soporta m√∫ltiples frames a la vez).

‚Ä¢ Solo exporta elementos compatibles con formato SVG.

‚Ä¢ No incluye im√°genes rasterizadas, texto plano ni auto layout como exportables.

‚Ä¢ No detecta autom√°ticamente cambios de selecci√≥n; requiere usar el bot√≥n ‚ÄúActualizar selecci√≥n‚Äù.



-----------------------------------------


This plugin lets you export graphical elements (assets) as SVG files from any selected Frame in Figma.


When you run the plugin:

1. It scans the selected frame for valid exportable elements (e.g., VECTORS, ICONS, COMPONENTS).

2. You‚Äôll see a list of assets with preview thumbnails, names, and their Figma types.

3. You can filter by type, toggle selection, and bulk-select assets.

4. Clicking ‚ÄúExport Selection‚Äù downloads all selected assets as a clean ZIP file of SVGs.


How to use it:

‚Ä¢ Select a Frame that contains the assets you want to export.

‚Ä¢ Launch the plugin.

‚Ä¢ Use the filters, select assets, and export.


Current limitations:

‚Ä¢ Only one Frame can be selected at a time.

‚Ä¢ Only elements that support SVG export will be included (e.g., no bitmaps or text layers).

‚Ä¢ Does not automatically react to new selections ‚Äî use the ‚ÄúRefresh Selection‚Äù button manually when needed.
plugins.tagline: Exporta f√°cilmente assets SVG desde frames seleccionados en Figma, con vista previa y filtros.

plugins.name: Heurator
plugins.description:
Elevate your design critique process with Heurator, a powerful Figma plugin that brings Nielsen's 10 Usability Heuristics directly into your workflow.


Document, visualize, and solve usability issues with precision‚Äîall without leaving your design files.


‚úì Pinpoint violations with customizable severity ratings

‚úì Generate visually striking evaluation cards linked to problem areas

‚úì Create actionable recommendations to improve user experience

‚úì Maintain consistent evaluation criteria across your team


Even in the age of AI-generated interfaces, human-centered heuristic evaluation remains essential. While AI excels at creating visually appealing designs, it often misses nuanced usability concerns that experienced designers catch. Heurator bridges this gap by helping you apply proven principles to any interface‚Äîwhether human or AI-designed‚Äîensuring truly intuitive experiences.


Transform complex usability principles into practical insights and deliver more thoughtful, user-centered designs with Heurator.
plugins.tagline: Because Even AI-Generated UIs Need Human-Centered Evaluation

plugins.name: Syntax Manager
plugins.description:
Syntax Manager helps you efficiently organize and apply code syntax (Web, Android, iOS) to your Figma variables. Whether you're prepping for development or just keeping things tidy, it streamlines your syntax workflow.


Core Features

  1. Filter variables by syntax status: all, with syntax, or without
  2. Narrow results by variable library or specific folder
  3. Search by variable name or syntax label
  4. Clean table view displaying variable names and their assigned syntax (Web, Android, iOS)
  5. Inline syntax editing: click directly on the syntax to edit it on the spot
  6. Multiselect with quick Select/Deselect All
  7. Floating action bar to apply updates or remove syntax for selected or all variables
  8. Custom syntax input field with {value} dynamic placeholder support
  9. Prefix dropdown (Auto / Name / Syntax) to control how the template is applied
  10. Advanced find/replace patterns using > and multiple replacements separated by ; for flexible syntax modification


Key Benefits

  1. Saves time: Batch-edit syntax across multiple variables in seconds
  2. Reduces errors: See all syntax at a glance and avoid inconsistencies
  3. Flexible control: Customize syntax naming conventions with smart placeholders
  4. Streamlines handoff: Align design tokens with dev-ready syntax for every platform
  5. Scales effortlessly: Perfect for small projects or massive variable libraries


How to Use

  1. Choose your view: filter by syntax presence or focus on specific libraries/folders
  2. Search or scroll to find relevant variables
  3. Select variables manually or use Select All
  4. Click directly on any syntax cell to edit it inline, or use the footer bar to add, update, or remove syntax
  5. Enter a custom syntax name (or leave it blank to use the variable name) or use find>replace patterns or ; for multiple replacements to transform parts of variable names (for instructions click the (?) icon)
  6. Apply your changes ‚Äì done!
plugins.tagline: Syntax management for variables made effortless.

plugins.name: QR Code Generator
plugins.description:
Generate QR codes without leaving Figma. Customize with your own link, logo and colors.


This plugin creates static QR codes in SVG format, so they can be resized without losing quality. It uses RecodeQR to generate the image (no account needed). The QR codes are fully self-contained: they don‚Äôt rely on our service and they‚Äôre yours forever.


Tip: To scan QR codes you can use the camera app on iOS, or you can also inspect them online.

plugins.name: Hot Spot
plugins.description:

plugins.name: Text Auto Fill
plugins.description:
Figma Plugin User Guide for Beginners


What It Does

This Figma plugin lets you update text and hide layers in selected frames or instances. It‚Äôs easy to use with a text-based configuration for both specific and global changes.


How to Use It

  1. Select a Frame or Instance: In Figma, click a frame or instance to edit.
  2. Open the Plugin: Run the plugin from Figma‚Äôs menu (Plugins > Your Plugin Name).
  3. Enter Configuration: In the plugin window, type instructions to change text or hide layers (see examples below).
  4. Click Run: The plugin applies your changes instantly.


Configuration Examples

‚Ä¢ Change Specific Text: To update text in a layer named title inside a frame named block, type:

block.title: Hello World

This sets the title layer‚Äôs text to "Hello World".


‚Ä¢ Change Text Globally: To update all layers named text in any frame, type:

text: Welcome

This changes every text layer‚Äôs text to "Welcome".


‚Ä¢ Hide a Specific Layer: To hide a layer named subtitle in the block frame, type:

//block.subtitle

This hides the subtitle layer.


‚Ä¢ Hide a Layer Globally: To hide all layers named icon, type:

//icon

This hides every icon layer.


‚Ä¢ Rename a Frame: To rename a frame named block, type:

$Title block: New Frame Name

This renames the frame to "New Frame Name".


‚Ä¢ Combine Actions: Mix specific and global changes, like:

block.title: Welcome
text: Hello
//block.subtitle
//icon

This updates block.title to "Welcome", all text layers to "Hello", hides block.subtitle, and hides all icon layers.


Tips

  1. Write one instruction per line.
  2. Layer names must match exactly (case-sensitive).
  3. Select at least one frame or instance, or you‚Äôll get an error.
plugins.tagline: Automatically update text in frames with key-value data

A smarter way to manage your Figma color variables


Prism is a powerful, easy-to-use plugin built to help you create, organize, and maintain a clean, scalable color system in Figma. Whether you‚Äôre building from scratch or refining an existing system, Prism takes the heavy lifting out of color management.


It‚Äôs the same powerful tool we use to power the Lumos Design System ‚Äî with token-based color management built right in.


‚∏ª


‚ú® What Prism does best

‚Ä¢üé® Full Color System

Instantly generate a complete color palette (from 50 to 900) based on your base colors.

‚Ä¢üîó Semantic Color Mapping

Create semantic color variables that stay linked to your base palette.

‚Ä¢üåó Light & Dark Theme Support

Effortlessly manage color values for both light and dark modes.

‚Ä¢üß∞ Visual Color Editor

Tweak colors visually with a real-time preview ‚Äî no guesswork required.

‚Ä¢üìÅ Clean, Organized Structure

Keeps your color variables tidy and consistent with logical naming and folders.

‚Ä¢üß© Built for Design Tokens

Prism follows a token-based approach inspired by the Lumos Design System, making it easy to plug into any design system workflow.


‚∏ª


Prism helps you focus on what matters ‚Äî great design ‚Äî by handling the complexity of color systems behind the scenes. Perfect for design systems, large projects, or anyone who wants a more organized Figma file.

plugins.name: Sizr
plugins.description: Sizr is a Figma plugin designed to streamline the process of resizing elements within a frame. By leveraging the column grid layout of the parent frame, the plugin ensures precise alignment and proportional scaling of selected elements. Whether you‚Äôre working with rectangles, text layers, groups, or components, Column Sizr dynamically calculates the appropriate dimensions based on the grid‚Äôs column count, margins, and gutter size. Simply select your elements, define the desired number of columns, and let the plugin handle the rest. Ideal for designers aiming for consistency and accuracy in grid-based designs.
plugins.tagline: Resize elements dynamically based on the column grid of their parent frame.

111068.name: Sizr
111068.description: Sizr is a Figma plugin designed to streamline the process of resizing elements within a frame. By leveraging the column grid layout of the parent frame, the plugin ensures precise alignment and proportional scaling of selected elements. Whether you‚Äôre working with rectangles, text layers, groups, or components, Column Sizr dynamically calculates the appropriate dimensions based on the grid‚Äôs column count, margins, and gutter size. Simply select your elements, define the desired number of columns, and let the plugin handle the rest. Ideal for designers aiming for consistency and accuracy in grid-based designs.
111068.release_notes:
Support for Components
Added:
- The plugin now supports resizing elements based on the grid of a parent `COMPONENT` in addition to a `FRAME`.
- Automatically detects whether the parent is a `FRAME` or `COMPONENT` with a valid grid layout.
- Displays appropriate notifications if resizing is restricted (e.g., when dealing with a master component).

Fixed:
- Improved error handling and user feedback for unsupported parent types or missing grid layouts.

How to Use:
1. Select an element within a `FRAME` or `COMPONENT` with a grid.
2. Trigger the plugin to resize compatible elements based on the grid layout.
111068.tagline: Resize elements dynamically based on the column grid of their parent frame.

plugins.name: Lint copy
plugins.description:
Lint copy helps UX writers and content designers automatically enforce style rules with a custom word list.


Enforce things like plain language (e.g. detect "utilize" and suggest replacing it with "use"), the company's voice and tone (e.g. detect "we are" and suggest using the contraction), and even product terminology.


Create a custom word list in JSON and host it in a public GitHub repository to experience the plugin's full power.


The plugin also enforces sentence case and strings starting with a capital, neither of which is customizable.


For full details, read the documentation.
plugins.tagline: Check text layers against a word list to enforce style, voice, and terminology.

plugins.name: Text Harvest
plugins.description:
Text Harvest exports and updates text layers in bulk with a CSV file

Get a quick CSV file from your designs for your copywriting or localization team.


Export

  1. Make a selection or export the entire page if there's no selection
  2. The plugin export only the visible layers, and also ignore the duplicated ones
  3. You'll get a CSV file with layer names and its content
  4. You can skip text layers that you don't want to export by simply adding the symbol "!" at the beginning of the layer name


Update

  1. Make a selection or update the entire page if there's no selection
  2. Select the CSV file
  3. The plugin updates all the layers with the same name


Currently multicolumn CSV are not supported. If you need to translate to different languages, upload an independent CSV for each one
plugins.tagline: Export and updates text layers in bulk with a CSV file
